Comment: 1 - in person visits provide a huge barrier for rural areas where you might need to drive over 2 hours one way for an in person visit that may not happen.  Our local office you cannot schedule an appointment, you have to take a number and wait - I'm in Case Management and I've had staff wait for hours before they were able to get a 10 minute appointment to fix an issue for a client that we serve.  This could mean people having to take entire day off work to try to get seen, and if they do not have a car, finding someone else with a car that could take them.  2 - able body work requirements requires that burden of proof is on you to prove you can't work, and if they decide you have to work to keep your insurance, you need to be able to find a job that you have skills for - also more difficult in some areas rather than others  3 - child's insurance - most people I know cannot afford to add their children to their work place insurance - some times people choose to work less because they need to keep their household income below a certain level to keep their child's insurance, if the child has a medical need.  These are some complexities to the medicaid arguments that while they may not seem valid to other people, to the people that are in these categories, it is very valid to them.
